column4: What is the advantage to building your drivers from source rather than just using the restricted drivers system already implemented in ubuntu?
Vid drivers that is...
mostly you do that if you need to use a custom kernel
i havent heard anything to suggest that compiling your video drivers would improve performance over restricted drivers
however, there are performance improvements to be had (for games esp) by using a realtime kernel
which is what i did, compiled custom kernel, then had to use the nvidia.com drivers
I dont know what a realtime kernel is. Can you expand on that a bit?
the realtime kernel is basically just the linux kernel with more aggressive timing, its scheduler or clock can be set to run faster
a good example is when i installed the ET:QW demo, it mentioned in its readme that a realtime kernel with 1000hz clock setting was recommended
cool... I had no idea. Are there plenty of links to be found by google-ing "realtime kernel"?
oh ya tons, and if u dont wanna compile your own there is also ubuntu's linux-kernel-rt package in the repo
dont get to choose your options with that package but you get a realtime kernel without having to recompile (which takes a little learning)
tho if oyu're serious about getting "under the hood" with your linux system, this guide makes recompiling your kernel relatively easy: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=311158
I like to learn. I've been thinking about rolling my own kernel for some time now. I think it's time I learned. Any tips before I plunge into google search madness?
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=311158
thx man... i'm reading now.
doing it with ubuntu makes it relatively painless, the part you'll spend most time on is configuring your kernel (choosing what options to use, or what drivers to compile into the kernel)
which is better... to compile into the kernel or to add as module? Is it faster to build it into the kernel?

well, back in the day (5 years ago) it was beneficial to compile into the kernel (the resulting kernel after compiling will be smaller)...but these days with systems having lots of ram and cpu power, u can use modules without any real performance impact
i went ahead and compiled in some specific drivers for my hardware tho, just because sometimes modules can be tricky, and in one case i needed a driver compiled in (snd-hda-intel) to work properly

only thing that kinda scares me is the fact that I have software (fake) raid... I sure don't want to hose that. But I suppose I can just use grub to load the old kernel if I get it wrong and try again.

actually its a good thing to compile a kernel with raid support (and filesystems) built-in, that way u wont have boot problems (RAID root partition cannot be mounted at boot time without kernel support)
im running a software raid too
in the tutorial you linked for building a custom kernel, nothing is said about x86 vs x64 systems... Do I need to download a special kernel for 64 bit systems?
